According to the ZeroNet website's presentation (how it works), when you create a zite, you get a private key and a public key. Where is this private key stored?

I'm looking into how exactly the signature along with a site owner's private key and the zite address (which I believe acts like the public key) works. As far as I understand it, when the site owner modifies his zite, he signs the content.json file, which creates the signature by encrypting a message (which I think is later used to verify the content.json file after being decrypted by the visitor) with the owner's private key. Then, when someone visits the zite, they download the content.json file and verify the signature by decrypting it with the public key (the zite address). I am wondering if this is correct or not, or if there is anything I missed, etc.? This information will be used in a tutorial that I am currently writing for the ZeroNet Dev Center Zite.

### Regarding A Common GPL Misconception
**Directly from the GPL 2 license:**
> For example, if you **distribute** copies of such a program,
> **whether gratis or for a fee**, you must give the **recipients** all
> the rights that you have.  You must make sure that *they*, too,
> ***receive* or can get the source code.**  And you must show them these terms so they know their rights.
It says you can charge a fee, and that you must release (or provide a way to get) the source code to (for) the *recipients* of the product, meaning *if it is paid, only to people who bought the software*, not everyone. *Note that I believe this is probably what used to be done with Red Hat since the Linux kernel uses GPL 2.* However, Red Hat recently joined with CentOS, so they basically just release the source code to everyone now.

## [Solus 3 Released](https://solus-project.com/2017/08/15/solus-3-released/)

[ZeroNet Dev Center](/14pM9huTYzJdyQyHRj6v2kfhMe8DrxwpGt/?/) Small Update:
* You can now follow:
   - Comments on Blog Posts
   - Questions
   - Answers
   - Your Questions (shows any answers on your question in the news feed)
* Two types of searching (for questions)
   - *Strict*: Only shows results that have matches with all of the words in your search, this was the old way of searching (before inclusive became the default)
   - *Inclusive*: Shows results that have at least one match from the words in your search, results with most matches show at the top, this is the new default search type
   - The top results on inclusive will actually match the results from strict, but inclusive has more results afterward

Just found an interesting consequence of my type system in Lydrige, aliasing through setting variables. However, this does not set them to their own type. In the image below, i32 == int:

Working on `and` and `or` functions for Lydrige. The `and` function is pretty much done. `and` returns true (0) if *all* given arguments evaluate to true (0). It returns false (1) if *any* argument evaluates to anything but true (0) (because false means everything other than 0).

This is another interesting language design choice I made: `true` and `false` are opposite from C. Instead of false being 0 and true being anything but 0 (like in C/C++), true is 0 and false is anything but 0.

I've had this same question from two different people already regarding [ZeroMedium](/ZeroMedium.bit), So I'm going to put my answer here: **How do you add images to your story?**

* You must use the Image Upload Button to *upload* an image
* You cannot link to an image from the internet (or outside source)
* You must put the editor in focus before clicking the upload button
* There might be some bugs with Image Upload for phones. I am looking into this.
* File names that have characters other than Latin/English cannot be used - this is a ZeroNet thing, not a ZeroMedium thing.

Is it possible to implement something like Open Graph for ZeroNet. I feel like this would be really cool for cross-sharing on multiple zites.

 I guess the main problem would be getting the information from a zite when the user hasn't downloaded that zite yet. But if they do have it downloaded, then the information can be shown.

Perhaps we can make this as a merger zite. When ZeroMe needs to access some information provided by another zite, it can access an "opengraph" table in the merger zite, which will have these rows: description, title, type, link, and image.

For zites that want to allow other zites to get information on the post, they can add it to the merger zite database, giving it the description, title, link, and image.

## ZeroGraph
I have created a way to get something like OpenGraph in ZeroNet, called ZeroGraph. It's simply a merger zite. It is nowhere near done (not as many options, no instructions on how to integrate into your zites, etc.).

## On Bug Reports
People need to learn how to create bug reports. **Don't skip things that you have done.** Give *step-by-step instructions* on what you did. Don't say: `I clicked the signin, but it's still telling me "Please login first"`. You should be saying:
`I clicked on the signin button, selected my id. The dialog closed/didn't close and my user did/didn't change. Whenever I click to post a comment/new story, it still says "Please login first"`. This is the type of bug report I'm looking for!
If there are bugs in ZeroMedium, you can report them on the Git Center Repo here: [/1BEPbMfV8QtaZCD2cPNbabfDKnmhTAZRPx](/1BEPbMfV8QtaZCD2cPNbabfDKnmhTAZRPx)

## Something Else
Originally written on May 1st, 2016

You say you're here
you spend your time so near,
but it seems you don't really care,
You got what you need, now you're gone
Now you're gone, so rare

Those many years, together we all were,
supporting each other, I was so sure
yet now it must be lost
More drifting to worsen --
It was us, aside, you tossed

You show no love,
Not regret, no fear of your --
that affect the people around,
Selfish, so selfish you act
Not giving any thought to the aspect
of your actions

Why now, why ever
Why when I need you most
to figure out the ways
of this mess --
And your help to find my own,
my place, Family's job you waste

A family teaches, helps, guides,
you've done none, nothing at all
you left us, cold, waiting, pleading
for the help, support, the guidance
we've been here, waiting, and needing --

You're always gone, never here,
you've become the opposite of promise
the opposite of support, of family

## [ZeroMedium](/ZeroMedium.bit) 17.12a Release
### New Features
* You can now use markdown link syntax: `[Link Title](link_address)`
* You can now put space or punctuation after markdown for it to automatically change to visual version. Punctuation includes: . , ! ? ( ) [ ] { }
* You can now add images while editing a story

### Bug Fixes
* Empty responses and stories are *kinda* disallowed (There is still a bug that I'm unsure how to fix)
* The "publish" button is temporarily disabled after clicking it when publishing a response. This prevents people from accidentally clicking it twice, which will post the response twice.
* Images that are uploaded will have the date uploaded appended to the filename. This ensures that there are no collisions with image names.
* For images that are uploaded with non-ascii characters in the filename, the non-ascii characters are removed - this is to prevent a ZeroNet bug with non-latin characters. Spaces are also replaced by underscores and quotes (double and single) are removed.
* The registration will not continue until you select a primary language and enter a username.
* When posting edited story, if title is same as before, no need to add date to end of it
* When interests is empty and you click to follow an interest, do not start the interests string with a comma ','. This prevents there from being an empty interest

## Concerning ZeroMedium Release Dates
I have decided to do a very small change with how versions are released for ZeroMedium. The final release date for new versions will *not* change. What *will* change is when versions are released to ZeroMedium BETA. Upon the final release of a new version to the official zite, the next version after will also be released to ZeroMedium BETA. *This will give beta versions at least 2 weeks for bug fixes* before being released to the official zite. This also means that I will be working two versions ahead of the official zite.

So what does this mean now? It means that later today (it just turned 12:00am as I am writing this) I will release the next version (17.12b) to ZeroMedium BETA. However, because I did not have much time to get this version out, this version will not have very many changes.

I just found something interesting out:
When registering an id on a certificate authority (id provider), the auth address of the "Unique User" for the zite becomes the auth address of your new id.

Okay, so I know basically how ZeroId works. The user's information is sent to a server. The server verifies it and sends back a task to do. The client does the task and sends a solution to the server. Once the correct solution is received, the server adds the certificate information to ZeroId's database. Once that happens, the client updates, looks through the "users" table for the current user, finds which "cert_.json" file to look at, and get's the certificate from that file and verifies the id was created.

Now, I know that KaffieId doesn't rely on a server, and uses the certAdd cmd, but does it have a database that stores all of the user's ids? I'm guessing not because that would have to rely on an id provider, right? So how do clients verify ids that come from KaffieId?

For the 18.01 Update for [ZeroMedium](/ZeroMedium.bit), I am going to try to optimize the SQL Queries as well as integrate the top stories ranking in an sql query rather than doing it in javascript. The benefit of this is that it will be more efficient and use less memory, because then I can limit the query (it will give back limited amount of rows) and won't need to store every single story from the dabase in a Javascript variable.

This will also help ZeroNet proxies because the ranking will be done before the data is sent to the person viewing the page along with the row limit, which means there would be less data to send to that person's computer.

ZeroExchange Progress Update: Got Searching working.

I just used the same searching algorithm I created for Dev Center and used for ZeroMedium, because I think it produces pretty good results - it orders things by relevance, putting highest priority with words from the search that match the tags, next being the title, next the username, and the last priority being the body. If a particular word from the search query has no matches, it will lower the result by one [they are basically like ordering points, I guess], unless it's in strict mode, then a result that doesn't match all words from the query will not be shown. If none of the words from the query match the result, it won't be shown (in *and* out of strict mode). You can see the algorithm [here](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroExchange/blob/master/src/router_pages/topic_search.vue#L62).

However, the main problem with this algorithm is that it needs *all* of the possible results (all questions in this case) to be stored in a variable and used in order for it to be accurate. Therefore, you can't do a database limit, offset, and pagination. So, I am going to eventually experiment with implementing something in SQL so that we can do the pagination stuff and still have a good searching algorithm.

Look at this crazy SQL query that I'm writing for ZeroMedium. Can you guess what it does?
```sql
SELECT stories.*, story_json.directory,
    (SELECT COUNT(*)
        FROM responses
        WHERE stories.story_id=responses.reference_id 
            AND REPLACE(story_json.directory, 'users/', '')=responses.reference_auth_address
            AND responses.reference_type='s'
        ORDER BY date_added DESC) AS num1,
    (SELECT COUNT(*)
        FROM claps
        WHERE stories.story_id=claps.reference_id
            AND REPLACE(story_json.directory, 'users/', '')=claps.reference_auth_address
            AND claps.reference_type='s'
        ORDER BY date_added DESC) AS num2
FROM stories
LEFT JOIN json AS story_json USING (json_id)
ORDER BY num1 ASC, num2 ASC, stories.date_added DESC;
```

On top of that, it's not actually what I want - I need to take the sum of the counts and order by that (but I don't know how to do that).

Here's the new code for determining ZeroMedium's "Today's Top Topics". I have reimplemented the previous JS implementation in SQL so that it is quicker, I can limit it, i can add pagination (offset and limit) (perhaps a new "Today's Top Stories" page could be added in the future), and i think it will be quicker for proxies:
```javascript
var that = this;
var now = Date.now();
var dayTime = 8.64e+7;

var topQuery = `
     SELECT stories.*, story_json.directory, value,
         ((SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT body)
             FROM responses
             LEFT JOIN json as response_json USING (json_id)
             WHERE stories.story_id=responses.reference_id 
                 AND REPLACE(story_json.directory, 'users/', '')=responses.reference_auth_address
                 AND REPLACE(story_json.directory, 'users/', '')!=REPLACE(response_json.directory, 'users/', '')
                 AND responses.reference_type='s'
                 AND (${now} - date_added) <= ${dayTime}
             ORDER BY date_added DESC)
         + (SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT clap_json.directory)
             FROM claps
             LEFT JOIN json AS clap_json USING (json_id)
             WHERE stories.story_id=claps.reference_id
                 AND REPLACE(story_json.directory, 'users/', '')=claps.reference_auth_address
                 AND REPLACE(story_json.directory, 'users/', '')!=REPLACE(clap_json.directory, 'users/', '')
                 AND claps.reference_type='s'
                 AND claps.number>=1
                 AND (${now} - date_added) <= ${dayTime}
             ORDER BY date_added DESC)) AS sort_num
     FROM stories
     LEFT JOIN json AS story_json USING (json_id)
     LEFT JOIN keyvalue USING (json_id)
     WHERE key='name'
     ORDER BY sort_num DESC, stories.date_added DESC
     LIMIT 5
     `;
```

**Edit:** Made the claps distinct by directory (and therefore user). This prevents someone from hacking this by adding multiple claps for a post as different rows. Also only count claps with number above 0 (0 means they had a clap originally, but removed it - so those ones should *not* be counted).
**Edit 2:** Added Distinct body when counting responses so posts with exact same message aren't counted twice. Helps to prevent spam (and accidental double posts) from skewing the results.

### [Important Zites](/1MiS3ud9JogSQpd1QVmM6ETHRmk5RgJn6E) Update:
* New Merger Zite category
* Putting "-" before a word in the search input will match everything that does *not* match the word. This will also essentially exclude things that match the word from the results *as long as it's the only word in the search input*. If it's not, the result *may* match other words from your search query. This is because a result must only match *at least one* word from the search - I'm calling this "inclusive mode". I will implement a "strict mode" later on where results must match *all* words in the search input.

### ZeroNet Windows MSI Installer
I have created a very simple msi installer that will put the ZeroNet files (from ZeroNet Windows Bundle on zeronet.io website) into a ZeroNet folder in Program Files (you can specify a different directory also) and create start menu shortcut for the main ZeroNet.exe file, the data directory, and the other executables (openssl, tor, meed-client, etc). It will also put a ZeroNet shortcut on desktop, and allow uninstallation from Control Panel.

I've also made the installer append the application/installation directory to the PATH environment variable so that the ZeroNet exe file can be accessed from the cmd prompt.

It's not much different from just extracting a zip file, etc. but it makes it a bit easier, and I think every bit counts.

You can download it here on this GitHub issue, in the last link of the second comment: [https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/1429](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/1429)
Do people still use the [old Important Zites](/15Pf9VVuDT8NSWj1qUBh4V89yPmrmzRw6a/)? It seems most of the time it has more peers than the [new one](/1MiS3ud9JogSQpd1QVmM6ETHRmk5RgJn6E/).

I have created a new installer (using Inno Setup) that is an Exe rather than an MSI. It now has the option to disable Adding to Start Menu and now includes a shortcut to the uninstaller within the Start Menu (as well as link to website). This file is also smaller than the MSI one.

This new installer will be the one that I'll be updating in the future.

You can download it [here](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/1429#issuecomment-390453050).

## Resitering for a KxoId
I have created a new ID Provider that allows unique usernames while keeping all requests/messages within ZeroNet by utilizing the PeerMessage plugin (created by @git center). To Register:
1. You must first download the PeerMessage plugin. You can do this by downloading the zip of the repository [here](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/Plugin-PeerMessage/archive/master.zip) and putting that into ZeroNet's plugins folder, **or** by using my [ZeroNet Windows Installer](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroNet-Windows-Exe-Installer/releases/download/1.4/ZeroNetInstaller.exe).
2. Then, go to the [KxoNetwork website](/1GTVetvjTEriCMzKzWSP9FahYoMPy6BG1P). Click Register (top right).
3. First, try to type "krixano". You should get an error that it already exists.
4. Next, type an id that you would want. This id must be unique (as shown in step 3) and cannot contain spaces.
5. As soon as the id is sent, it is verified on one of my "trusted clients" and a message of it's success (and the signed certificate) is sent back to your client and saved. You will automatically be logged in after this (your username should replace the login and register buttons in the top left of the website).

### Question for KxoVid Users

Why are you using KxoVid over KopyKate Big? KopyKate Big has more users and is more active. This certainly goes against the Network Effect, right?

While users has an effect on the value of a zite, it's not the **only** value. The value of the features of a zite can go beyond the value of it's users - which is hopefully when new zites gain more users. Of course, this only matters if we had proper discoverability, and people actually *try* to discover new things.

Anyways, thanks for using KxoVid.

### For Non-KxoVid Users

Why should you use KxoVid? Here's Why:
* Merger Zites - less centralization - no one owner who controls what videos are shown/allowed
* KxoId Support - KxoId is the first id provider that offers unique usernames while ensuring requests are handled inside the ZeroNet network, including if you are using Tor. It will also be federated in the future (I'm getting close to being done with this). Also supports ZeroId for people who don't want to get a KxoId (for some reason)
* *Optional* Chromecast Support
* Playlists
* Better design, especially for mobile
* Doesn't allow resources added by users (thumbnails, for example) to require loading from the clearnet - better on privacy and security
* Multiple channels per user id
* Much Better searching and Related Videos

I live in the US. My time zone is America/Chicago (aka CST). I am free weekends from 12AM to 12PM, MWF (monday, wednesday, friday) from 2PM to 12AM, and TTh (tuesday, thursday) from 12PM to 12AM.

The point of open-source software is not to freely give away your work in return for nothing. The point is that programmers can learn from and reuse code from other project to continue growing and expanding the technology and methods used in new products (or the same product). It's not unlike how the arts work....

In the arts there's this thing called copyright, which used to last for the lifetime of the artist plus some years. Why? So nobody can steal their work as their own until enough time has passed for the credit to be clearly distinguished - and then it's "open-sourced" in the end so that people can eventually reuse and learn from it. This is how it **should** work, imo.

Just like anything, open source software comes at a price - the price that another person or company can come along and steal your code and give you no credit. *This is fine in a world where you can sue these people for not obeying the license's terms* (in the case you have something in your license that requires giving credit) - but small companies and single person's likely don't have the time or money to sue or get lawyers.

And this is *especially* problematic in ZeroNet, where everything is decentralized and anonymized. You can't sue someone when you can't even figure out who they are, where they live, their ip address, etc.

I think people miss the point of open-source software. They're equating open vs. closed as good vs. evil - which is ridiculous imo. Keeping something closed forever makes no sense, imo - and I will agree to that. But there *is* a point to making something closed for a period of time - it's called Copyright (the original idea of copyright). A person should get credit for what they do - and that's the stance I take.

Btw, I'd like to point out that the majority of people vehement about closed-source software I don't think are thinking logically or realistically about the actual benefits closed-source software may provide in specific circumstances, and they are oblivious to the real problems open-source software actually has (and yes, it **does** have problems). Neither open- nor closed-source software are perfect, and people need to realize this.

### This is the license that KxoVid and any zites that I create in the future will use:

During the lifetime of the original author (Christian "Krixano" Lee-Ethan Seibold), the MPL v1.1 license applies. After the original author's death, the MIT license applies.

MPL v1.1: 
https://tldrlegal.com/license/mozilla-public-license-1.1-(mpl-1.1)

MIT:
https://tldrlegal.com/license/mit-license

Using `Router.hooks` will call the provided `before` and `after` functions for *every* route. I will *soon* have hooks that you can pass into the `add` function when you add a route so the `before` and `after` functions are only called for that specific route.

@Antyhrabia: Do you mean what a router is. Really all it is doing is taking your query string and parsing it. If it matches anything that you have defined with the `add()` function, then it will call your function you have provided to the `add()` function. So, let's say I wan't to switch out the inner html of an element based on what page they are on. I want it where if someone goes to `1K2myjtjoEVpRC2JMieRL73ES4V4iLP2Ev/?/about`, I will replace the innter html of a div with information regarding the `about` page. This allows me to dynamically change out content without refreshing the page everytime.

@Krixano: If I wanted to add a link from the home page to the about page, I would write this: ``` About Page ``` And what this will do is, when someone clicks on the link, it will first change the url in the address bar to `.../?/about`, then it will run the function that I passed in to `router.add()` when I added the `about` route. This function just changes the inner html of the div tag with the id of `out`. And all of this is done dynamically, without refreshing the page.

Here's the [example zite](/1K2myjtjoEVpRC2JMieRL73ES4V4iLP2Ev) that shows it functioning. And here's [the code](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroFrame-Router/blob/master/example/index.html) for that zite. I hope I explained this well enough for you.

@Polar: It's not because many have already done the migration. What you are talking about are the addons that have features that aren't supported in WebExtensions. Not *every* extension is like that. Also, any extensions that have Chrome versions *can* be migrated because Chrome uses webextensions (there are some incompatibilities I think). And anyways, there's nothing that says WebExtensions aren't going to be improved.

I think it is much more important to keep the browser fast an secure than to have powerful extensions. This is what Mozilla has focused on with this version. To say it's crap because not all of your addons are supported (especially when you haven't given the devs enough time to migrate the extensions) makes no sense to me because extensions is only **one** part of the browser (you don't give 1 star to an app if they only missed a small feature that you want - if you do, that's kinda crap). I get it, you want the old extensions back, but security should come before that I think, and as far as I know, WebExtensions are more secure *because of* their limitations. An added benefit is that extension devs can use more of the same code between Chrome and Firefox versions. Also, WebExtensions will make plugins not break everytime Mozilla wants to add new features to their browser. Overall, I think this change had to come sooner or later (multiprocess Firefox would have broken many extensions anyways). Obviously it'll be tough to migrate all the extensions, or wait for features to allow some of the ones that wouldn't currently be supported to be migrated, but you just need to be patient.

@Shouko: Correction, I think `allLoad.sh` loads all the zites from the addresses so their directories (for the ones that exist) appear in the ZeroNet data directory (I could be wrong, but I think that's what `lynx -dump "$url"` does). Then in `listUsed.sh`, it adds all the addresses that have directories to a file called `realAddresses.txt`. Then `searchJsonGen.js` creates the json file and looks at the content.json files of each zite to get the name and description. Finally, `knowledgeGatherer.sh` generates 0list.json for zites on 0list, copies the name.json file, and counts the number of zites from 0list.

@Polar: And here's searchAuthAddress, where it searches for the current user. This function looks through the users listed in the "users" and archived users json files for the current user's username. Once it finds it, it looks through the correct "cert_" json file to find the certificate.
```
searchAuthAddress: (search, cb) ->
		@setStatusTitle "Searching for : #{search}"
		found = 0
		found_cert = false
		pending_request = 0
		for user_name, cert of @users
			if cert.startsWith("@")
				[cert_file_id, auth_address_pre] = cert.replace("@", "").split(",")
				if search.startsWith(auth_address_pre) or user_name == search
					found += 1
					cert_filename = "certs_#{cert_file_id}.json"
					@setStatusTitle("Recovering certificate from #{cert_filename}...")
					@log "Possible optional file cert: #{cert} #{user_name}"
					pending_request += 1
					@loadCert "data/#{cert_filename}", user_name, (user_name, cert) =>
						pending_request -= 1
						[auth_type, auth_address, cert_sign] = cert.split(",")
						if auth_address == search or user_name == search
							found_cert = true
							@log "Found valid cert: #{cert}"
							cb(user_name, cert)
						else
							@log "Invalid cert: #{cert}"
						if pending_request == 0
							@log "Found cert: #{found_cert}"
							if not found_cert
								cb(false, false)
			else
				[auth_type, auth_address, cert_sign] = cert.split(",")
				if auth_address == search or user_name == search
					@log "Cert found directly: #{cert}"
					found += 1
					cb(user_name, cert)
		if found == 0
			cb(false, false)
```

Therefore, after the server adds the users certificate to the zite, it signs and publishes the zite. The client receives this update, which calls these two functions that I have posted below to verify that the current auth address has a certificate (and username, etc).

@Git Center: Now that that was cleared up, can you tell me which parts of the tutorial you were misunderstanding, because this misunderstanding may have been on my part. Perhaps there was a section that wasn't explained enough, or wasn't explained clearly enough?

@Git Center: When a user registers for a provider, they are given a signature. This signature is just the user's information (username, portal type, and auth_address) put into a string and encrypted with a private key. This signature gets copies over to not only your `data/users.json` file, but also any `content.json` file you have on any other zite. When ZeroNet verifies that a user belongs to a particular id provider, all it has to do is decrypt this signature (from your `content.json` file inside your user folder on the zite) using the id provider's public key and check that the information from that decrypted string is the same as what is in the user's content.json file (because the content.json also lists the username, portal type, and auth address is given from directory). The only question is how does ZeroNet know the public key of an Id Provider? This is actually very simple. It can get it from what the Zite Owner put in the "cert_signers" part of their `data/users/content.json` file (the part where you put something like `"kaffie.bit": [ "1KH5BdNnqxh2KRWMMT8wUXzUgz4vVQ4S8p" ]`). This public key for KaffieId was given on the homepage.

> Also, do you know when are ZeroID users verified? E.g. can I change my data/users/.../content.json's cert_user_id to nofish@zeroid.bit and signature to use nofish?
You can now see where the problem with decentralized Id Providers lies. You cannot do this with ZeroId because you need ZeroId's private key to be able to create the signature. However, you *can* do this with KaffieId (e.g. changing your username to glightstar@kaffieid.bit) because it's private key is public. This would pretty much be the same as using that change username feature on the KaffieId zite, except that it will store the changed username in your `data/users.json` file for you (but you could do it manually yourself).
-
Basically, the way ZeroNet verifies users is very similar to how it verifies zites, by using these signatures that were encrypted by private keys. It decrypts them and checks if they match what they should (hash of content.json for zites, user info for users).

@Git Center: You should also note that user auth addresses have a private key as well. So, even if you were able to get nofish's signature from ZeroId database, you'd still have to be able to sign the content.json file with his user's private key.

@caryoscelus: I have seen that people think it gives https protection for non-https website. But that isn't quite what it does. All it does is make sure you are using the https version of the websites/links, which means https has to be supported by the website in the first place. I believe it also uses a whitelist, so it only works for the sites on the whitelist. The description it gives on chrome addons page isn't completely clear that it only works for https-supported sites (and on a whitelist).

From their website:
> HTTPS Everywhere protects you only when you are using encrypted portions of supported web sites.
> ...
> For example, if your web mail provider does not support HTTPS at all, HTTPS Everywhere can't make your access to your web mail secure. Similarly, if a site allows HTTPS for text but not images, someone might be able to see which images your browser loads and guess what you're accessing. 

and

> HTTPS Everywhere can protect you **only when you're using sites that support HTTPS** and for which HTTPS Everywhere **include a ruleset.**

This is why I consider the addon a little useless, imo (because to me, it seems that https websites are always going to give their links in https and many of them automatically redirect from http to https, especially the one's popular enough to warrant being on HTTPS Everywhere's whitelist).

@ssdifnskdjfnsdjk@zeroid.bit: The current (and only) "trusted client" right now is my computer. PeerMessage basically lets you broadcast messages to all clients on ZeroNet in the same way zite/file updates happen, except it's never stored on the hard drive (only in memory), so there's no need for a delay.

When you register, your username is encrypted with the zite's public key (so that only the zite owner can decrypt and see the username you are registering) and is broadcasted with this plugin to 5 clients. Then all the clients that have the PeerMessage plugin will broadcast to more clients until it reaches one of the "trusted clients" (the only one right now being my computer). These trusted clients have a *private* webpage with code that has the private key so that it can decrypt info being sent and so that it can encrypt the certificate (after verifying it's uniqueness) and send it back to be used as your id. Hope I explained that well enough.

---

@Kaffie: While I agree with you, I don't like merger zites as much as CORS. CORS achieves the same thing, and is easier to use/setup. @Moor: So, are you saying that having open-source licenses that require giving credit to the original project isn't within the scope of open-source, or are you saying you can't sue if someone doesn't follow the open-source license (because if so, then why even have FOSS licenses that have these limitations)?

@Moor: My argument has nothing to do with competition. It has everything to do with **credit**.
Hence:
> A person should get credit for what they do - and that's the stance I take.
.
Btw, something that people seem to miss or deliberately skip is that closed-source software incentivizes coding good-quality code in a timely fashion (otherwise you lose money) - something which open-source doesn't really have and is the reason why a lot of open-source software is bad quality. With open-source software, you can just put the blame or *responsibility* off on the open-source community rather than taking the responsibility for yourself.

@Moor: 
> now, credit is a legal issue as i mentioned previously

Actually, you *didn't* mention this previously. Doing a Search right now, no mention of the word "credit" or "legal" in your paragraph whatsoever.
.
Additionally, Open-Source licenses have limitations that require credit be given, notice of changes, etc. (one such license is MPLv1.1) - so it *is* within the scope of Open Source.
.
*And,* the whole point about talking about suing is that you *cannot* sue someone who you don't know anything about - therefore, open sourcing your code is a **risk** that someone can easily steal it *without giving credit* and you have **no way** of suing that person. With closed-source, you don't have this risk.

@caryoscelus: The two main things I wanted from a license was Must "Give Credit" and Cannot Use "contributors' names, trademarks, or logos". I don't quite like that patents are allowed, but whatever.
Additionally, I **didn't** want MPLv1.1 to apply forever, therefore I added that the license switches over to MIT once I die.

@caryoscelus: You're presuming that I deliberately chose MPLv1.1 over MPLv2 for a reason.
.
I don't remember exactly why when I chose this license, but I think it might have had to do with the fact that MPLv1.1 **directly** states that credit must be given, while with v2 it's more *indirect* - credit's given through "including original" and "including copyright"
.
Also, while I don't care *too* much about this, stating changes is kinda nice for the user.
